On 05/01/2008, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
>
>  While it is certainly possible that they have deeper insights than
>  those they offered, it seems a bit strange that they would fail to
>  share them at a debate headlined as "evolution and complexity" in
>  front of an audience of Ph.D. scientists.  So it's not unreasonable
>  to conclude they don't have a lot to say on the subject that is
>  particularly groundbreaking.
[...]
>  Most people at GECCO who I spoke to after the debate echoed the
>  sentiment that they hadn't really learned much, and in fact, had
>  heard deeper insights on evolution and complexity during GDS-track
>  (Generative and Developmental Systems, a track at GECCO) paper talks
>  than during the keynote event.

I'd agree with that. It seemed like they thought they were addressing
the general public - the way they were explaining some fairly basic
concepts, stuff that anyone at GECCO would already know inside out.

Now I know these guys do field questions from Joe Public (JP) from
time to time (Dawkins expecially) and have to explain and argue for
evolution over and over, and I imagine it gets a bit tiring (I
personally always avoid any such discussion with JP because I know
that most often I'll just get annoyed), and it must be easy to slip
into default 'defensive' mode when in fact that wasn't necessary.

Anyway it seemed to me that some of these questions were being asked
to get a deeper response (as might be expected from such a crowd) but
that they were interpreted as coming from JP and that the panel got
the wrong end of the stick and a little defensive at times. E.g. When
Wolpert curtly dismissed Lamarckism - well no-one there was actually
suggesting Lamarckism as an alternative to Darwinian evolution. I am
glad they were aware of recent work on epigenetics though - I was
beginning to wonder if they had read any recent works.

Colin
